revision.text:
{{POV|date=August 2015}} [[File:Shoelace cropped photograph.jpg|thumb|Shoelace pose, a classic pose or ''asana'' of Yin yoga, a more meditative style of yoga.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thetravelyogi.com/yoga-for-travelers/|title=Yoga for Travelers|accessdate=January 1, 2017}}</ref> The shoelace pose opens the hips, and is said to affect the liver meridian in the groin and the gallbladder meridian along the outer hip and leg.]] '''Yin yoga''' is a slow-paced style of [[yoga]] with postures, or ''[[asanas]]'', that are held for longer periods of time—for beginners, it may range from 45 seconds to two minutes; more advanced practitioners may stay in one ''asana'' for five minutes or more.<ref>{{cite web |url= |title= Slow stretch, side of soul: Tight muscles, tough thoughts demand attention at Yin yoga |last1= Loriggio |first1= Paola |last2= |first2= |date= |work= |publisher= Toronto Star |accessdate=January 8, 2013}}</ref>
Yin yoga poses apply moderate stress to the [[connective tissue]]s of the body—the tendons, fascia, and ligaments—with the aim of increasing circulation in the joints and improving flexibility. A more meditative approach to yoga, yin aims at cultivating awareness of inner silence, and bringing to light a universal, interconnecting quality.<ref name="Yoga Journal">{{cite web|last1=Sexton|first1=Michael|title=YJ Interview: The Delight of Insight|url=http://www.yogajournal.com/article//yj-interview-delight-insight/|website=YogaJournal.com|publisher=Yoga Journal|accessdate=16 November 2014|date=Nov 13, 2009}}</ref>
Yin yoga's teaching in the Western world, beginning in the late 1970s, was founded by martial arts expert and [[Tao]]ist yoga teacher [[Paulie Zink]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Norberg|first1=Ulrica|title=Yin yoga: and individualized approach to balance, health, and whole self well-being|date=2014|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing|location=New York|isbn=9781626363953|page=23 |quote= Yin yoga is a rapidly growing approach of yoga that has its roots in the United States and was introduced in the late 1980s by martial arts champion and yogi Paulie Zink through his fusion of Taoism and yoga, called Taoyoga.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.yjconferenceconnection.com/mar09_yj_conference.html|title= Teacher Spotlight: Paulie Zink The founding master of Yin yoga|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= March 2009|work= Conference Connection|publisher= Yoga Journal|quote= Paulie, the founding master of Yin yoga, started practicing at the age of 14 ... Paulie began teaching Taoist yin and yang yoga in the late 70's|accessdate=February 12, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.yogamagazine.com/yin-yoga/|title= Yin yoga|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |work= |publisher= Yoga Magazine|quote= Yin yoga is a synthesis Paulie Zink created by combining hatha yoga and several disciplines from the Taoist tradition along with insights, visualisations, and animal based yoga postures, movements, and vocalisations he developed himself|accessdate= February 12, 2013}}</ref> Yin yoga is now being taught across North America and in Europe, due in large part to the teaching activities of Yin yoga teachers and developers Paul Grilley and Sarah Powers.<ref name=kinosian>{{cite news |title= Yin yoga: yang-style's less aggressive counterpart: Taoist-based practice targets the connective tissues, ligaments, joints and synovial fluid |author= Janet Kinosian|url= http://articles.latimes.com/2009/sep/21/health/he-yin-yoga21 |newspaper= Los Angeles Times |quote= Paul Grilley, a martial arts and yoga practitioner, who helped develop Yin yoga along with Sarah Powers... From Los Angeles to London, so called Yin yoga is increasingly being taught at studio classes and yoga retreats, not to mention via books and DVDs |date= Sep 21, 2009|accessdate=January 6, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Lisa Maria 82">{{cite news |title= Soothe Yourself|author= Lisa Maria|url= http://www.yogajournal.com/practice/2677|page= 82|newspaper= Yoga Journal|date= Sep 2008|quote= Much of the Yin Yoga practiced in the United States today was introduced by Paul Grilley in the late 1980s. |accessdate=January 6, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jill|first1=Paget|title=Yin yoga--A Brief Introduction|journal=Yoga Scotland|date=January 2013|page=9|url=http://www.yogascotland.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Yoga-40-Cover.pdf|quote= Paul Grilley, the teacher who has brought the yin way of practising yoga to prominence, has very aptly described Yin yoga as "A quiet Practice."}}</ref><ref name="Achy Joints? How Yin Yoga Can Help">{{cite journal|last1=Gamerman|first1=Amy|title=Achy Joints? How Yin Yoga Can Help|journal=The Oprah Magazine|date=June 2012|volume=13|issue=6|accessdate=6 July 2015|quote= 'Yin yoga is joint rehabilitation,' says Paul Grilley, the godfather of the movement.|url=http://www.oprah.com/health/Yin-Yoga-Good-for-Joints-Slower-Yoga}}</ref> Yin yoga as taught by Paul Grilley and Sarah Powers is not intended as a complete practice in itself, but rather as a complement to more active forms of yoga and exercise.<ref>{{cite book |last= Grilley|first= Paul|authorlink= |title= yin Yoga: Principles and Practice|url= |accessdate= |year= 2012|publisher= White Cloud Press|location= Ashland Oregon|isbn= 9781935952701|page= xi|pages=| quote = It was never my intention to promote Yin yoga as an independent system of asana practice because Yin yoga is, by definition, incomplete. It was and is my intention to promote Yin yoga as a supplement to yang forms of exercise. . . . Yin and yang forms of yoga balance each other.}}</ref> However, Paulie Zink's approach includes the full range of Taoist yoga, both yin and yang, and is intended to be a complete practice in itself.<ref name=Bernie/>{{rp|21}}
==History==
===Roots in India and China=== The practice of holding yoga postures or ''asanas'' for extended periods of time has always been a significant part of traditional yoga practice, both in the hatha yoga tradition of India and in the Taoist yoga tradition of the greater China area. Contemporary schools of hatha yoga have also advocated holding some poses for relatively long periods of time. For example, [[B. K. S. Iyengar|BKS Iyengar]] recommended holding the [[Supta Virasana|Supta Virasana asana]] (reclining hero pose) for 10–15 minutes.<ref name=Bernie/>{{rp|12}} For that matter, long-held stretches have been and are commonly recommended in other physical disciplines, such as gymnastics and dance, to increase flexibility. For example, ballerinas are commonly counselled to open their hips by approximating the splits position for long periods of time.<ref name=Bernie/>{{rp|28}}
Taoist yoga practices from China also included yin-style poses in the Taoist system of "[[Neidan|Internal Alchemy]]"—practiced for the purpose of improving health and longevity.<ref name=Bernie/>{{rp|15}} Techniques for stretching of this type have been practiced for centuries in China and Taiwan as part of Taoist yoga, which was sometimes known as Dao Yin. Taoist priests taught long-held poses, along with breathing techniques, to [[Kung Fu]] practitioners beginning 2000 years ago, to help them fully develop their martial arts skills.<ref>{{cite news |title= The Lost Art of Flexibility |author= Michael Gonzales |newspaper= Black Belt Magazine |page= 66|date= Dec 1983}}</ref>
===Beginnings in the West=== [[File:Paulie Zink--Yin Yoga--BEST.jpg|thumb|Paulie Zink]]The practice of performing series of long-held floor poses one after the other was first introduced in North America in the late 1970s by Paulie Zink, a martial arts champion and Taoist yoga teacher and practitioner.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Solan|first1=Matthew|title=Talking shop with Paul Grilley|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vOkDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA24&lpg=PA24&dq=paulie+zink+taoist+yoga&source=bl&ots=Qf962iwmla&sig=es9JjKkdxEJOQyHtU48nKMdEToE&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Y9OxU-bkDpPZoASc7oCADQ&ved=0CD0Q6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=paulie%20zink%20taoist%20yoga&f=false|website=Google Books|publisher=Yoga Journal|accessdate=June 30, 2014}}</ref> Zink trained for 10 years, during the 1970s, in daily private classes with Cho Chat Ling, a Kung-Fu and Taoist yoga master from Hong Kong specializing in ''Tai shing pek kwar,'' or Monkey Kung Fu. (In Kung Fu, the movements of animals are closely studied and emulated, inspiring many of the movements taught in Kung Fu.) At the end of the decade, Zink entered the Long Beach International Karate Championships in 1981, 1982 and 1983 and won Grand Champion in the "weapons forms" category in all three years, and was also Grand Champion in the "empty hands" category in two of those years.<ref>{{cite news |title= Long Beach Internationals|author= David W Clary |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=39YDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA50&dq=A+Final+Farewell+to+Ed+Parker&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SDz2UJ_BL8eViALX-oCoBQ&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=A%20Final%20Farewell%20to%20Ed%20Parker&f=false |page= 82|newspaper= Black Belt Magazine |date= Nov 1991|quote=|accessdate=January 15, 2013}}</ref> Black Belt magazine named him Kung Fu artist of the year in 1989.<ref>{{cite news |title= Black Belt Hall of Fame Awards: Awards to Date|author= |page= 59|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=OdYDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA5&dq=Black+Belt+Hall+of+Fame+Awards+august+1991&hl=en&sa=X&ei=QoD5UNG8MObziwKa7oGYBw&sqi=2&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Black%20Belt%20Hall%20of%20Fame%20Awards%20august%201991&f=false|newspaper= Black Belt Magazine |date= August 1991|accessdate=January 6, 2013}}</ref> Noted in the Kung Fu community for his exceptional personal flexibility,<ref>{{cite news |title= Table of contents|author= |page= 5 |newspaper= Black Belt Magazine |date= December 1983}}</ref> Zink also emphasized flexibility training in his martial arts classes as a method to develop agility, power and endurance.<ref>{{cite news |title= The Lost Art of Flexibility |author= Michael Gonzales |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=bdIDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA5&dq=%22the+lost+art+of+flexibility%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=RoP5UNC_OsOmigK4rYGgCg&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22the%20lost%20art%20of%20flexibility%22&f=false|page= 66 |newspaper= Black Belt Magazine |date= Dec 1983|accessdate=January 6, 2013}}</ref>
In the late 70s, Zink began, separate from his martial arts classes, to teach a synthesis of hatha yoga with a range of disciplines from Taoist Yoga, as well as postures, movements and insights that he had developed himself. He later called this synthesis "Yin and Yang yoga," or often "Yin yoga" for short.<ref name=Bernie/>{{rp|19}}<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kragie|first1=Eileen|title=Yin yoga: The Complete Art Form Founded by Paulie Zink|journal=Elephant Journal|date=June 27, 2014|url=http://www.elephantjournal.com/2014/06/yin-yoga-the-complete-art-form-founded-by-master-paulie-zink-eileen-kragie/|accessdate=3 July 2015}}</ref><ref name="yogamagazine1">{{cite web |url= http://www.yogamagazine.com/yin-yoga/|title= Yin yoga |last1= Zink |first1= Paulie|last2= Zink|first2= Maria|date= March 2012|work= |publisher= Yoga Magazine |accessdate=January 8, 2013}}</ref> Paulie Zink, even more than his master, was convinced of the effectiveness of holding yoga poses for long periods of time in order to improve flexibility.<ref name=Bernie/>{{rp|20}}
In his first years of teaching, many of Zink's students were martial artists who had developed strong but tight muscles, and he taught them only beginner level Taoist yoga, focusing on long-held yin poses to allieviate their lack of flexibility. However, as more students came he began to teach more advanced levels. He explained that in order to develop full flexibility, the student must restore his own primal nature, through several Taoist yoga practices, as follows: yin ''asanas''— mostly sitting or lying postures; yang ''asanas''— more active, strenuous postures; Taoist Flow yoga— both yin and yang yoga postures practiced in continuous, smooth and circular motions; ''Chi Kung'' (or Qigong)— involving simple and gentle movement and breathing techniques; and Taoist alchemy— based upon the Taoist theory of the five elements used in Chinese medicine.<ref name=Bernie/>{{rp|19}} <ref name="yogamagazine1"/> Taoist Alchemy is a method of embodying the energetic attributes of various animals and enlivening the five alchemical elements believed to be contained in the body's energetic field. The five transforming energies of Earth, Metal, Water, Wood, and Fire animate distinct qualities in the body such as calm, strength, fluidity, springiness and lightness, respectively.
===Paul Grilley and Sarah Powers=== Paul Grilley, a yoga teacher who later became a major proponent of Yin yoga,<ref name="Lisa Maria 82"/><ref name="Achy Joints? How Yin Yoga Can Help"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jill|first1=Paget|title=Yin yoga--A Brief Introduction|journal=Yoga Scotland|date=January 2013|page=9|url=http://www.yogascotland.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Yoga-40-Cover.pdf|quote= Paul Grilley, the teacher who has brought the yin way of practising yoga to prominence, has very aptly described yin YToga as "A quiet Practice."}}</ref> first saw Paulie Zink on a public access television talk show in California in 1988, performing a demonstration of Taoist yoga practices that he used in teaching martial arts. Impressed by both his exceptional physical flexibility and his gentle, restrained manner, absent the arrogance he had observed in other martial artists, he sought Zink out and studied with him for about one year.<ref name= Grilley>{{cite book |last= Grilley|first= Paul|authorlink= |title= yin Yoga: Principles and Practice, 10th anniversary edition|url= |accessdate= |year= 2012|publisher= White Cloud Press|location= Ashland Oregon|isbn= 9781935952701|page= xiii|pages=}}</ref>
Earlier, Grilley had formally studied anatomy for two years in his home state, Montana, under Dr. Garry Parker. He moved to California and continued studying anatomy at UCLA. There, he also regularly taught hatha yoga for several years—active forms including Ashtanga and Bikram's--and managed a yoga studio.<ref name=Bernie/>{{rp|21}} In 1989, Grilley met Hiroshi Motoyama, a Japanese scholar and yogi,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Maria|first1=Lisa|title=Soothe Yourself|url=http://www.yogajournal.com/practice/2677|accessdate=30 June 2014|publisher=Yoga Journal|date=Sep 2008}}</ref> who had researched the physiology of Traditional Chinese Medicine and written on it extensively.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jill|first1=Paget|title=Yin yoga--A Brief Introduction|journal=Yoga Scotland|date=January 2013|page=9|url=http://www.yogascotland.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Yoga-40-Cover.pdf}}</ref> Motoyama was especially interested in the physiology of the meridians, or subtle pathways and vessels, and the ''qi'' or subtle energy hypothesized to flow through or get stored in them. These are both fundamental concepts in Chinese medicine and acupuncture. He related these to the parallel concepts of the ''nadi'' pathways and ''chakras'' of Indian yoga, and the ''prana'' said to be carried within them.<ref name=GrilleyYJ>{{cite news |title= Yin yoga |author= Paul Grilley |url= http://www.yogajournal.com/practice/580 |pages= 80–90|newspaper= Yoga Journal|date= July–August 2001|quote= |accessdate=January 6, 2013}}</ref>
Grilley now began to teach a fusion of the Yin poses he had learned from Zink with his own knowledge of hatha yoga and anatomy, and the teachings of Motoyama.<ref name=Bernie/>{{rp|22}} <ref name="yogajournal82 q"/> He created yin sequences with aims similar to that of an acupuncturist.<ref name=Soothe>{{cite news |title= Soothe Yourself|author= Lisa Maria|url= http://www.yogajournal.com/practice/2677|page= 85|newspaper= Yoga Journal|date= Sep 2008|quote= Around the same time that Grilley was studying with Zink, he did a brief stint in acupuncture school . . . . working with Hiroshi Motoyama, . . . Grilley began to develop the energetic aspect of the practice: the long holds in Yin are thought to benefit the subtle body by targeting the meridians that run through the connective tissue of the hips and lower back |accessdate=January 6, 2013}}</ref> Yin teacher and author Ulrica Norberg says that Grilley, based on this fusion of knowledge, "evolved Yin yoga further."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Norberg|first1=Ulrica|title=Yin yoga: and individualized approach to balance, health, and whole self well-being|date=2014|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing|location=New York|isbn=9781626363953|page=23 |quote= Paul Grilley, Paulie's disciple, evolved Yin yoga further. . . . With his training from Paulie Zink and his academic background in anatomy from UCLA under his belt, he continued his studies with Dr Hiroshi Motoyama, a Japanese scientist whose primary topic is spiritual self and who taught him Chinese medicine, acupuncture, and the energetic system of the chakras.}}</ref> Bernie Clark, a leading Yin yoga author and teacher <ref>{{cite news|last1=Beirne|first1=Geraldine|title=Yin yoga: be part of the yin crowd|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2015/jan/05/yin-yoga-calm-mind-stretch-body-slow|accessdate=4 July 2015|date=January 5, 2015|newspaper= The Guardian |quote= One of the leading teachers of Yin yoga, Bernie Clark, says . . .}}</ref> said that Grilley's synthesis of anatomy, Taoist yoga, and meridian theory "resonated with many people who recognized the benefits of the practice and related to Paul's model of the body/mind/soul." <ref name=Bernie>{{cite book |last= Clark|first= Bernie|authorlink= |title= The Complete Guide to Yin yoga |url= |accessdate= |year= 2012|publisher= White Cloud Press|location= Ashland Oregon|isbn= 978-1-935952-50-3|page= |pages= |quote= Paul combined the knowledge he had been given on anatomy, Daoist yoga, and the meridien theory, and this became the core of his Yin Yoga teachings--which resonated with many people who recognized the benefits of the practice and related to Paul's model of the body/mind/soul.}}</ref>{{rp|22}}
One of Grilley's students, Sarah Powers, also a yoga teacher, began teaching yoga in Grilley's style. She incorporated Buddhist psychology in her teaching of Yin yoga and put even more emphasis on targeting the meridian systems for health and enlightenment than did Grilley. Much of her book, ''Insight Yoga,'' is devoted to an explanation of Yin yoga sequences designed to enhance the flow of ''qi'' as understood in Traditional Chinese Medicine.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Maria|first1=Lisa|title=Insider's Guide--A veteran teacher explores the depths of yoga and self-inquiry, creating a manual for inner peace|journal=Yoga Journal|date=Feb 2009|pages=111–112}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=August 2015}} She also emphasized a conscious and systematic approach to breathing during yin practice.<ref name= Powers>{{cite book |last= Powers|first= Sarah|authorlink= |title= Insight Yoga|url= |accessdate= |year= 2008|publisher= Shambala|location= Boston|isbn= 978-1-59030-598-0|page= |pages= 26–27}}</ref>
Grilley at first called it Taoist yoga, in deference to the term Paulie Zink had used. Sarah Powers pointed out that the yoga she and Grilley were teaching was different from the Taoist practice being taught by Zink. She suggested they use the term Yin yoga, to differentiate it from the various forms of Taoist yoga being taught. She and Grilley adopted the name.<ref name=Bernie/>{{rp|22}} Later, Paulie Zink also began calling his teachings Yin yoga, though as a short form for his preferred term, "Yin and Yang Yoga."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kragie|first1=Eileen|title=Yin yoga: The Complete Art Form Founded by Paulie Zink|journal=Elephant Journal|date=June 27, 2014|url=http://www.elephantjournal.com/2014/06/yin-yoga-the-complete-art-form-founded-by-master-paulie-zink-eileen-kragie/|accessdate=3 July 2015 | quote =Paulie refers to his art as Yin and Yang yoga, but often uses the term “Yin yoga” for short.}}</ref>
===Teaching spreads=== Sarah Powers, already a renowned yoga teacher who traveled widely giving yoga workshops, now began also teaching Yin yoga in her tours.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Clarke|first1=Bernie|title=Original Yin|url=http://www.yinyoga.com/ys1_1.1_original_yin.php|website=YinYoga.com - The Home Page of Yin yoga|publisher=yinyoga.com}}</ref> When her students asked for more information, she would refer them to Paul Grilley, who began receiving requests to travel and offer seminars. Paulie Zink continued teaching Yin yoga in his own style, combined with other elements of Taoist yoga. Powers and Grilley began offering Yin yoga teacher training courses, as did Paulie Zink. Over the next 10 years, Yin yoga became available all over North America and in Europe, through yoga classes, and via DVDs and books.<ref name=kinosian/> In 2002, Grilley published the book, ''Yin yoga: A Quiet Practice'' (and in 2012 a revised edition titled, ''Yin yoga Principles and Practice''). In 2006, Biff Mithoefer, a student of Grilley and Powers, published The Yin yoga Kit, which included a detailed volume of instruction as well as a DVD. In 2008, Sarah Powers published the book, ''Insight Yoga,'' which teaches Yin yoga sequences and more active (or yang) yoga sequences as a complement to yin poses.<ref>{{cite news |title= Insider's Guide |author= Lisa Maria |page=111|newspaper= Yoga Journal |date= February 2009}}</ref> Bernie Clark, also a student of Grilley and Powers, began the website, yinyoga.com, in 2006 and published his book, ''The Complete Guide to Yin yoga'' in 2012. Both Grilley and Powers have also released instructional DVDs on Yin yoga, as has Paulie Zink.
==Practice== [[File:IMG 0222 2- Caterpillar.jpg|thumb|IMG 0222 2- Caterpillar | Caterpillar pose: In Yin yoga, poses are held for an average of five minutes—much longer than poses are generally held in other schools of yoga—with the objective of improving flexibility and restoring a fuller range of motion.<ref>{{cite book |last= Powers |first= Sarah |authorlink= |title= Insight Yoga |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=5V9fo0w6eKoC&printsec=frontcover&dq=insight+yoga&hl=en&sa=X&ei=vTeJUd2hLIuOigKpi4CYAw&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAA|accessdate= |year= 2008|publisher= Shambahala |location= Boston |isbn= 978-1-59030-598-0|page= |pages= 46–47 }}</ref>]][[File:IMG 0438 2-1- Saddle pose.jpg|thumb|IMG 0438 2-1- Saddle pose| Saddle pose: This pose stretches the feet, knees, thighs, and arches the lumbar and sacral vertebrae. It is said to stimulate the Kidney meridian as well as the kidneys themselves.<ref>{{cite book |last= Grilley|first= Paul|authorlink= |title= yin Yoga: Principles and Practice|url= |accessdate= |year= 2012|publisher= White Cloud Press|location= Ashland Oregon|isbn= 9781935952701|page= 74|pages=| quote = }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= Powers |first= Sarah |authorlink= |title= Insight Yoga |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=5V9fo0w6eKoC&printsec=frontcover&dq=insight+yoga&hl=en&sa=X&ei=vTeJUd2hLIuOigKpi4CYAw&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAA|accessdate= |year= 2008|publisher= Shambahala |location= Boston |isbn= 978-1-59030-598-0|page= |pages= 39–41 }}</ref>]]
[[File:IMG 0549 2 Sphinx.jpg|thumb|IMG 0549 2 Sphinx | Sphinx pose: In the more advanced version of this pose, the "Seal," the arms are fully extended and the back bend is deeper. Seal pose is similar in appearance to the Cobra pose of hatha yoga, but is performed differently (see "Distinction from hatha yoga"). The same is true of other yin poses and their similar versions in hatha yoga.<ref name="yogajournal87">{{cite news |title= Soothe Yourself|author= Lisa Maria|url= http://www.yogajournal.com/practice/2677|page= 87|newspaper= Yoga Journal|date= Sep 2008|quote= |accessdate=January 6, 2013}}</ref>]]
Paulie Zink's approach to Yin yoga consists of both yin and yang postures, and also incorporates movement in between postures as a yang element.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.yogamagazine.com/yin-yoga/|title= Yin yoga|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |work= |publisher= Yoga Magazine|quote= |accessdate= February 12, 2013}}</ref> In contrast, Yin yoga sessions taught by Paul Grilley and Sarah Powers consist of a series of long-held, passive floor poses—which Grilley learned from Paulie Zink <ref name="yogajournal82 q">{{cite news |title= Soothe Yourself|author= Lisa Maria|url= http://www.yogajournal.com/practice/2677|page= 82|newspaper= Yoga Journal|date= Sep 2008|quote= Much of the Yin Yoga practiced in the United States today was introduced by Paul Grilley in the late 1980s. Grilley’s approach has a physical and an energetic aspect. He discovered the physical aspect when he met Taoist Yoga and martial arts teacher Paulie Zink and was immediately inspired. “I’d pretty much exhausted the power of vinyasa, Bikram—you know, anything heavy, hot, and sweaty, I’d already done it,” Grilley says. “Paulie’s practice was like a huge breath of fresh air, because his approach to the postures was first yin on the floor and then yang, and neither of them was that similar to my previous practice.|accessdate=January 6, 2013}}</ref>—that primarily affect the lower part of the body—the hips, pelvis, inner thighs, lower spine—about 18 - 24 in number. These areas are especially rich in connective tissues, the "loading" of which (Yin yoga teachers avoid the word "stretching") is a main focus in this style of yoga.<ref name="yogajournal82"/> Grilley and Powers both emphasize the value of more active, yang-type poses, but do not generally mix yin and yang styles.
Yin yoga employs specific sequences of poses aimed at stimulating particular meridians, or subtle channels, as understood in Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM),<ref name= Surrender>{{cite news |title= Sweet Surrender|author= Andrea Ferretti |url= http://www.yogajournal.com/practice/2545|newspaper= Yoga Journal |date= June 2007|accessdate=January 6, 2013}}</ref> the far eastern counterpart of India's [[Ayurveda]]; the system of medicine claims that there are energy channels of the subtle body, called ''nadi'' (Sanskrit for "stream"), with the ''ida'', ''pingala'', and ''sushumna'' as the principal or most important ''nadis''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tantra-kundalini.com/nadis.htm|title=Tantra-Kundalini.com - Nadis of the subtle body|website=Tantra Kundalini|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=August 2015}}
During the long hold times of the yin asanas, teachers usually give "dharma talks," informal monologues drawing from a variety of sources, according to teachers' choice. They will often explain the physiology and anatomy of poses, including the location of the meridian lines being affected. They may tell traditional Buddhist stories, recite poetry, sing songs, or reflect on their own experience.<ref>{{cite book|last=Powers|first=Sarah|title=Insight Yoga (DVD)|year=2005|publisher=Pranamaya, Inc.|isbn=978-0-9763836-5-9|chapter=Introduction to Yin yoga}}</ref>
In keeping with its roots in Taoist yoga, Paulie Zink says that Yin yoga has a deeper purpose: to "open the heart and invoke the primal self."<ref name="yogamagazine1"/> Sarah Powers says one of the primary objectives of yin practice is the cultivation of inner stillness.<ref name="Yoga Journal"/>
==Principles==
===Yin and yang=== Yin yoga is based on the Taoist concepts of yin and yang, opposite and complementary principles in nature. Yin could be described as stable, immobile, feminine, passive, cold, and downward moving. Yang is understood to be changing, mobile, masculine, active, hot, and upward moving. The sun is considered yang, the moon yin.<ref name=About>{{cite web |url= http://yoga.about.com/od/typesofyoga/a/Yin-Yoga.htm|title= Yin yoga |last1= Pizer |first1= Ann |last2= |first2= |date= May 17, 2012 |work= |publisher= about.com Yoga |accessdate=January 11, 2013}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=August 2015}} In the body, the relatively stiff connective tissues (tendons, ligaments, fascia) are yin, while the more mobile and pliable muscles and blood are yang. More passive asanas in yoga are considered yin, whereas the more active, dynamic asanas are yang, because they stimulate the muscles and generate heat.<ref name="yogajournal82">{{cite news |title= Soothe Yourself|author= Lisa Maria|url= http://www.yogajournal.com/practice/2677|page= 82|newspaper= Yoga Journal|date= Sep 2008|quote= |accessdate=January 6, 2013}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=August 2015}}
===Distinction from hatha yoga=== Although many Yin yoga poses or ''asanas'' closely resemble the ''asanas'' in Indian hatha yoga, they have different names, in part to alert those who are familiar with similar poses in hatha yoga not to perform them in the same way.<ref name=About/> In general, the poses of Yin yoga are performed with very little muscular exertion. For example, in the Seal pose, in which a practitioner lies face down and then raises the trunk upward, the upward movement is gradual and entirely supported by the arms, and the legs are relaxed. But in the Cobra or ''Bhujangasana'' of hatha yoga, the practitioner actively curves the spine upward in an arc using arms and lower back muscles, and reaches back with the legs strongly.<ref name="yogajournal87"/>
===Physiology=== Muscles account for about forty percent of the resistance against the body's flexibility, while connective tissue accounts for about fifty percent.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://yinyoga.com/ys1_2.2.1.1_limits_flexibility.php |title= Limits of Flexibility |last1= Clark |first1= Bernie |last2= |first2= |date= |work= |publisher= YinYoga.com |accessdate=8 February 2013}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=August 2015}} The intensity and physical benefits of Yin yoga practice depend on two variables: duration of the asana, and the temperature of the muscle. Asanas are usually held for five minutes, but can be held for as long as twenty. Because of the long duration of asanas, it is said that patience is another of the key values cultivated by Yin yoga.
It is usually recommended that Yin yoga be practiced when the muscles are not yet warmed up. When the muscles are cold, they are less elastic, and more stress will be transferred to the connective tissue. However, this is a general rule and for some people, it is better to stay a bit warm while practicing. Because this style of yoga does not generate bodily heat, yin teachers recommend keeping the temperature of the room a little higher than usual.<ref name="Bernie"/>{{rp|33}} During yin asanas, muscles are relaxed to avoid [[tetany]], or muscle spasm, which could result from engaging muscles for long periods.
==Publications== * ''Yin yoga: Principles and Practice," 10th anniversary edition, Paul Grilley, White Cloud Press, Ashland, Oregon 2012 {{ISBN|978-1-883991-43-2}} * ''Yin yoga: Outline of A Quiet Practice'', Paul Grilley, White Cloud Press, Ashland, Oregon 2002 {{ISBN|978-1-935952-70-1}} (The original version of this book is titled ''Taoist Yoga: Outline Of A Quiet Practice'' by Paul Grilley) * ''Insight Yoga'', Sarah Powers, Shambahala Publications Inc., Boston, MA 2008 {{ISBN|978-1-59030-598-0}} * ''The Complete Guide to Yin yoga: the Philosophy & Practice of Yin yoga'', Bernie Clark, White Cloud Press, Ashland, Oregon 2012 {{ISBN|978-1-935952-50-3}} * ''Yinsights: A Journey into the Philosophy and Practice of Yoga'', Bernie Clark, Cardinal Publishing Group, Indianapolis 2007 {{ISBN|978-0-9687665-1-4}}
